resources.string: You will discover your specially dedicated application preparing for your next marathon.
We will help you set the best goal by depending on your profile. Our estimate is based on a database of results of a large number of athletes who have prepared for a marathon.

To give you the best estimate possible, we are going to ask you some questions about you and how you feel like prepare for this marathon. These questions will remain editable later if you want to change your answers.
Based on your answer to each question, the estimate of your time is calculated by our algorithm in real time, so feel free to test several answers if you hesitate between several !
4. What is your weight in Kg?
5. How many years have you been running ?
6. How many marathon have you done ?
7. How many training per week do you plan for this marathon ?
8. What are your preferred training days ?
9. What is the date of your marathon ?

Attention!

You want to train many times a week. If you are a beginner in running, it is important to start slowly.

Start with 1 or 2 training sessions per week and then increase if you feel capable.

If this is your first marathon, your main goal is to finish it!
The date of your marathon must be in more than 30 days.
Here are some tips for your marathon\'s preparation
Know your limits so you don\'t hurt yourself.
The first goal of a marathon is to finish it !
If you can\'t follow your preparation, better reconsider your goal.
One training session = one stretching session
If you often have body aches, force yourself to drink a lot of water.
During the race, find a group with the same objective as you and course in this group.
When you have a side stitch, press hard on it and blow while bringing your upper torso towards the ground.
If you want to refuel during the marathon, try to get there get used to doing it during your training.
During the race, it is better to force yourself to start slowly then pick up your pace.
\"If you want to run, run a mile. If you want to change your life, run a marathon.\", Emil Zatopek
Listen to your body to avoid injury. You should not force yourself.
If you have problems with aches and pains or anything else, don\'t hesitate to consult a physical therapist.
Biking is a great additional way to get stronger.
Avoid doing split sessions that are too intense, it can be a source of injury.
Avoid alcohol and tobacco as much as possible.
Don\'t try to go too fast, you need to be regular and have achievable goals.
The 30km marathon is an important psychological barrier, you should not go too fast at the beginning.
It is better to be well shod for the marathon. The ideal is to have shoes adapted to its specific shape of the feet.
Find someone who has the same physical conditions as you, in order to train and support each other.
No, in will not do it.
Choose a training to add on this day.
Long training: 1h10 at 75% of maximum heart rate.
Long training: 1h30 including 2 times 8 minutes at 85-90% MHR with a recovery of 2 minutes between each effort.
Long training: 1h30 including 2 times 10 minutes at 85-90% MHR with a recovery of 2 minutes between each effort.
Long training: 1h40 with 3 times 3000m at specific marathon pace or 80-85% MHR with a recovery of 2 minutes between each effort.
Long training: 2h00 with 3 times 4000m at specific marathon pace or 80-85% MHR with a recovery of 2 minutes between each effort.
Long training: 1h30 including 2 times 12 minutes at 80-85% MHR with a recovery of 2 minutes between each effort.
Fractional training: jogging 30 min, 2 series of 10x: 30s of effort at your maximum speed / 30s of recovery, 3 min between the series.
Fractional training: 20-30min jogging, 2 series of 10x: 200m at 100-105% vVO2max / 30s recovery between 200m and 3 min between each series.
Fractional training: 20-30min jogging, 2 series of 8x: 30s of effort at 100-105% vVO2max / 30s of recovery, 3min between each series.
Fractional training: 20-30 min jog, 12 series: 300m at 100% vVO2max / recovery of 45s to 1 min between 300m.
Fractional training: jogging of 20-30 min, 2 series 5x: 400m at 95% vVO2max / recovery of 1min10 each 400m and 3min each series.
Fractional training: 20-30 min jogging, 2 series 5x: 400m at 95% vVO2max / recovery of 1min10 each 400m and 3min each series.
Fractional training: 20-30 min jogging, 2 sets of 6x: 300m at 100% vVO2max / recovery of 1min each 300m and 3 min each series.
Muscular reinforcement: jogging 20 min, 2x: sheathing 45s at 1 min 30 on each side, recup 5 min between series.
Muscular reinforcement: 20 min jog, 3x: 15-20 push-ups, 5 min rest between sets.
Muscular reinforcement: jogging 20 min, 3x: 20 crunch, recovery 5 min between sets.
Muscular reinforcement: jogging 20 min, 3x: 20 squat, recovery 5 min between sets.
